getting-started

getting-started.Rmd
library(VickyA4)

Overview

This vignette shows how VickyA4 transforms three assignment PDFs into a reproducible corpus and how to explore it:

  1. PDFs are bundled under inst/extdata/.
  2. data-raw/course_dataset.R extracts text and metadata (pages, words, sentences).
  3. The result is stored as course_dataset (a tibble shipped with the package).
  4. launch_app() opens a Shiny UI that helps users reach similar conclusions to the original analyses by interactively exploring the corpus (e.g., document length, estimated reading time, quick comparisons).

The goal is traceability: anyone can rebuild the same dataset from the same PDFs, and see how the interactive interface guides interpretation.

The dataset 

# Print the full dataset
corpus_docs
#>                 source n_paragraphs n_words n_chars
#> 1 A1_breaking_articles           36    1314    8022
#> 2  A2_summarising_tech          144    1879   13025
#> 3     A3_blog_snapshot            8     851    5032

Columns (summary):

  • source: heuristic label ("A1", "A2", "A3") and a human-readable label derived from the file name.
  • n_paragraphs: paragraphs count from pdftools::pdf_info().
  • n_words: rough word count based on whitespace tokenization.
  • n_chars: approximate character count via punctuation.

Interpretation reminder: sentence detection is heuristic; treat read_minutes_est as indicative, not definitive.

Quick exploration in R

You can answer simple questions without leaving R.

Which assignment is the longest by word count?

corpus_docs[order(corpus_docs$n_words, decreasing = TRUE), 
               c("source","n_paragraphs", "n_words")]
#>                 source n_paragraphs n_words
#> 2  A2_summarising_tech          144    1879
#> 1 A1_breaking_articles           36    1314
#> 3     A3_blog_snapshot            8     851

paragraphs vs words:

with(corpus_docs, data.frame(n_paragraphs, n_words))
#>   n_paragraphs n_words
#> 1           36    1314
#> 2          144    1879
#> 3            8     851

Launch the Shiny app

The app is bundled under inst/app/ and reads course_dataset directly (no read.csv()):

launch_app()

Inside the app you can:

  • Select a document and read a concise summary (paragraphs, words, character).
  • Toggle details like file path.
  • Use the interface descriptions to understand what each field means and how to interpret the outputs.

This lightweight interactivity helps a user replicate key takeaways from the original assignments: - Identify which deliverable is more substantial (length/complexity proxy). - Benchmark reading effort for different pieces. - Provide a consistent, transparent basis for comparison.

Rebuilding the dataset (reproducibility)

To recreate course_dataset from the packaged PDFs:

# From the package root (development setting)
source("data-raw/corpus_docs.R")

This will regenerate data/course_dataset.rda.
If you add new PDFs to inst/extdata/, simply rerun the script; the corpus will update automatically.
